org.semanticweb.kaon2.api.logic
Interface Literal

All Superinterfaces:
Axiom, Fact, FactFormula, Formula
public interface Literal
extends Formula, FactFormula

Represents a literal in the rule. A literal consists of a predicate, a pattern representing the variable names or constants and a flag determining whether the literal is negated.

Method Summary
 boolean containsVariable(Variable variable)
          Returns true if this literal contains the supplied variable.

          Returns the argument at given position.

          Returns the arity of the literal.
 Term getModule()
          Returns the module of this literal, or null if no module has been supplied.
 Predicate getPredicate()
          Returns the predicate of this literal.
 PredicateSymbol getPredicateSymbol()
          If the predicate of this literal is a PredicateSymbol, then this method returns it; otherwise, it returns null.

 boolean isPositive()
          Returns true if this literal is positive (with respect to non-monotonic negation).

Returns true if this literal is positive (with respect to non-monotonic negation).

getPredicate

Predicate getPredicate()
Returns the predicate of this literal.

Returns:

getPredicateSymbol

PredicateSymbol getPredicateSymbol()
If the predicate of this literal is a PredicateSymbol, then this method returns it; otherwise, it returns null.

Returns:
the predicate symbol or null

getArguments

Term[] getArguments()
Returns the array of argument terms. This object is not owned by the literal (i.e. it can be changed without affecting this literal).

Returns:
the argument terms

int getArity()
Returns the arity of the literal.

the arity of the literal

replacePredicate

Literal replacePredicate(Predicate newPredicate)
Replaces the predicate of the literal. This method may be somewhat more memory efficient, because it attempts to reuse the arguments array.

Parameters:
newPredicate - the predicate of the new literal
Returns:
the literal with a new predicate

replacePredicateAndPolarity

Literal replacePredicateAndPolarity(boolean newIsPositive,
                                    Predicate newPredicate)
Replaces the predicate and polarity of the literal. This method may be somewhat more memory efficient, because it attempts to reuse the arguments array.

Parameters:
newIsPositive - the new polarity of the literal
newPredicate - the predicate of the new literal
Returns:
the literal with a new predicate

replaceModule

Literal replaceModule(Term newModule)
Replaces the module. This method may be somewhat more memory efficient, because it attempts to reuse the arguments array.

Parameters:
newModule - the new module of the literal
Returns:
the literal with a new module
